description: From Middle English bisides (also bisiden), extension of biside, equivalent to beside +‎ -s (adverbial suffix).

examples: It is besides used as a food, either as a sallad[sic], raw, or boiled as greens.

entries.meaning: (conjunctive) Used to emphasize an additional point, especially an important or stronger reason; moreover; furthermore.
examples: I don't feel like going out tonight. Besides, I have to work tomorrow morning anyway.
I have been to Spain but nowhere besides.
Yet Teucer would another shaft, at Hectors life dispose;  So faine, he such a marke would hit: but still besides it goes;

During the whole time of his abode in the university he generally spent thirteen hours of the day in study; by which assiduity besides an exact dispatch of the whole course of philosophy, he read over in a manner all classic authors that are extant […]

entries.meaning: Other than; except for; instead of.
examples: I don't want to go anywhere besides India.
And on the Sabbath day, we went out of the citie, beſides a riuer, where they were wont to pray : and we ſate downe, and ſpake vnto the women, which were come together.
